{"step_by_step_thinking": "A Type I error occurs when we reject the null hypothesis and erroneously state that the study found significant differences when there indeed was no difference. On the other hand, a Type II error occurs when we declare no differences or associations between study groups when, in fact, there was. In this case, the study finds no significant association between two variables but truly there exists a difference. This is a description of a Type II error.", "answer_choice": "B"}
